page.title: 20ANIMALS IN KETTLEWELL
page.content: Rabbits are the most numerous species in Kettlewell, with myxamatosis sadly showing a return after some years of dormancy. On Knipe End there are some black rabbits. There are hares and moles, with foxes sometimes seen in daylight. Rats occur frequently near agricultural holdings. The wood and field mouse, bank vole, common and pygmy shrew are found, together with hedgehogs and grey squirrels. Deer used to be common: however, roe deer are more plentiful than is generally realised. Occasionally badger sets are found. The main predators, apart from foxes, are stoats and weasels. Mink are becoming common and are causing havoc with breeding moorhens by the riverbank, and they have made water voles scarcer.
